title: Lab 1: Census Data Quality for Policy Decisions
text:
You are a data analyst for the California Department of Human Services. The department is considering implementing an algorithmic system to identify communities that should receive priority for social service funding and outreach programs. Your supervisor has asked you to evaluate the quality and reliability of available census data to inform this decision.
Drawing on our Week 2 discussion of algorithmic bias, you need to assess not just what the data shows, but how reliable it is and what communities might be affected by data quality issues.




Apply dplyr functions to real census data for policy analysis
Evaluate data quality using margins of error
Connect technical analysis to algorithmic decision-making
Identify potential equity implications of data reliability issues
Create professional documentation for policy stakeholders




Submit by posting your updated portfolio link on Canvas. Your assignment should be accessible at your-portfolio-url/labs/lab_1/
Make sure to update your _quarto.yml navigation to include this assignment under an “Labs” menu.

title: Lab 1: Census Data Quality for Policy Decisions
text:
You are a data analyst for the California Department of Human Services. The department is considering implementing an algorithmic system to identify communities that should receive priority for social service funding and outreach programs. Your supervisor has asked you to evaluate the quality and reliability of available census data to inform this decision.
Drawing on our Week 2 discussion of algorithmic bias, you need to assess not just what the data shows, but how reliable it is and what communities might be affected by data quality issues.

title: Lab 1: Census Data Quality for Policy Decisions
text:
Apply dplyr functions to real census data for policy analysis
Evaluate data quality using margins of error
Connect technical analysis to algorithmic decision-making
Identify potential equity implications of data reliability issues
Create professional documentation for policy stakeholders

title: Lab 1: Census Data Quality for Policy Decisions
text:
2.1 Data Retrieval
Your Task: Use get_acs() to retrieve county-level data for your chosen state.
Requirements: - Geography: county level - Variables: median household income (B19013_001) and total population (B01003_001)
- Year: 2022 - Survey: acs5 - Output format: wide
Hint: Remember to give your variables descriptive names using the variables = c(name = "code") syntax.

# Write your get_acs() code here
ca_county_data <- get_acs(
  geography = "county",
  state = my_state,
  variables = c(
    median_hh_income = "B19013_001",
    total_pop = "B01003_001"
  ),
  year= 2022,
  survey = "acs5",
  output = "wide"
)

head(ca_county_data)

# A tibble: 6 × 6
  GEOID NAME           median_hh_incomeE median_hh_incomeM total_popE total_popM
  <chr> <chr>                      <dbl>             <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl>
1 06001 Alameda Count…            122488              1231    1663823         NA
2 06003 Alpine County…            101125             17442       1515        206
3 06005 Amador County…             74853              6048      40577         NA
4 06007 Butte County,…             66085              2261     213605         NA
5 06009 Calaveras Cou…             77526              3875      45674         NA
6 06011 Colusa County…             69619              5745      21811         NA

# Clean the county names to remove state name and "County" 
# Hint: use mutate() with str_remove()

clean_data <- ca_county_data %>%
  mutate(
    NAME = NAME %>%
      str_remove(", California") %>%
      str_remove(" County")
  )%>%
  select(`County` = "NAME",
         `Median Household Income` = "median_hh_incomeE",
         `Median HH Income Margin of Error` = "median_hh_incomeM",
        `Total Population` = "total_popE",
        )

# Display the first few rows
head(clean_data)%>%
  kable()

Median Household Income
Median HH Income Margin of Error

title: Lab 1: Census Data Quality for Policy Decisions
text:
2.2 Data Quality Assessment
Your Task: Calculate margin of error percentages and create reliability categories.
Requirements: - Calculate MOE percentage: (margin of error / estimate) * 100 - Create reliability categories: - High Confidence: MOE < 5% - Moderate Confidence: MOE 5-10%
- Low Confidence: MOE > 10% - Create a flag for unreliable estimates (MOE > 10%)
Hint: Use mutate() with case_when() for the categories.

# Calculate MOE percentage and reliability categories using mutate()
ca_county_reliability <- clean_data %>%
  mutate(
    moe_pct = (`Median HH Income Margin of Error`/`Median Household Income`)*100,
    category = case_when(
      moe_pct < 5 ~ "High Confidence",
      moe_pct >= 5 & moe_pct <= 10 ~ "Moderate Confidence",
      moe_pct > 10 ~ "Low Confidence"
      ),
    flag = case_when(category == "Low Confidence" ~ "!!!",
                   TRUE ~ "    "  )
)
  

tibble(ca_county_reliability)

# A tibble: 58 × 7
   County       Median Household Inc…¹ Median HH Income Mar…² `Total Population`
   <chr>                         <dbl>                  <dbl>              <dbl>
 1 Alameda                      122488                   1231            1663823
 2 Alpine                       101125                  17442               1515
 3 Amador                        74853                   6048              40577
 4 Butte                         66085                   2261             213605
 5 Calaveras                     77526                   3875              45674
 6 Colusa                        69619                   5745              21811
 7 Contra Costa                 120020                   1496            1162648
 8 Del Norte                     61149                   4376              27462
 9 El Dorado                     99246                   3330             191713
10 Fresno                        67756                    967            1008280
# ℹ 48 more rows
# ℹ abbreviated names: ¹​`Median Household Income`,
#   ²​`Median HH Income Margin of Error`
# ℹ 3 more variables: moe_pct <dbl>, category <chr>, flag <chr>

# Create a summary showing count of counties in each reliability category
# Hint: use count() and mutate() to add percentages

count_reliability <- ca_county_reliability %>%
  count(category) %>%
  mutate(
    percent = n/sum(n)*100
  )%>%
  select(`Category of Reliability` ="category",
         `Count`= "n", 
         `Percentage`= "percent")
  tibble(count_reliability)%>%
    kable()




Category of Reliability
Count
Percentage




High Confidence

Moderate Confidence

title: Lab 1: Census Data Quality for Policy Decisions
text:
2.3 High Uncertainty Counties
Your Task: Identify the 5 counties with the highest MOE percentages.
Requirements: - Sort by MOE percentage (highest first) - Select the top 5 counties - Display: county name, median income, margin of error, MOE percentage, reliability category - Format as a professional table using kable()
Hint: Use arrange(), slice(), and select() functions.

# Create table of top 5 counties by MOE percentage

top_variable <- ca_county_reliability %>%
  arrange(desc(moe_pct))%>%
  slice(1:5) 
  
head(top_variable)

# A tibble: 5 × 7
  County  `Median Household Income` Median HH Income Margin…¹ `Total Population`
  <chr>                       <dbl>                     <dbl>              <dbl>
1 Mono                        82038                     15388              13219
2 Alpine                     101125                     17442               1515
3 Sierra                      61108                      9237               2916
4 Trinity                     47317                      5890              15889
5 Plumas                      67885                      7772              19650
# ℹ abbreviated name: ¹​`Median HH Income Margin of Error`
# ℹ 3 more variables: moe_pct <dbl>, category <chr>, flag <chr>

# Format as table with kable() - include appropriate column names and caption
top_variable <- ca_county_reliability %>%
  arrange(desc(moe_pct)) %>%
  slice(1:5)

top_variable %>%
  select(
    County,
    `Median Household Income`,
    `Median HH Income Margin of Error`,
    `Total Population`,
    `Margin of Error for HH Income (%)` = moe_pct,
    `Reliability Category` = category,
    DANGER = flag
  ) %>%
  kable(caption = "Top 5 counties in California by HH Income MOE")


Top 5 counties in California by HH Income MOE

Data Quality Commentary:
[These results show that counties with the highest margins of error for median household income, such as Mono, Alpine, Sierra, Trinity, and Plumas, have less reliable income estimates. Algorithms that rely on this data may therefore poorly serve residents in these counties by producing unstable classifications or inaccurate eligibility decisions. This uncertainty may lead to their exclusion or misrepresentation in planning decisions and program targeting that depend on precise income thresholds.]

title: Lab 1: Census Data Quality for Policy Decisions
text:
3.1 Focus Area Selection
Your Task: Select 2-3 counties from your reliability analysis for detailed tract-level study.
Strategy: Choose counties that represent different reliability levels (e.g., 1 high confidence, 1 moderate, 1 low confidence) to compare how data quality varies.

# Use filter() to select 2-3 counties from your county_reliability data
# Store the selected counties in a variable called selected_counties
# Display the selected counties with their key characteristics
# Show: county name, median income, MOE percentage, reliability category


selected_counties <- ca_county_reliability %>%
  filter(category %in% c("Low Confidence", "Moderate Confidence", "High Confidence")) %>%
  group_by(category) %>%
  slice(1) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  select(
    County,
    `Median Household Income`,
    `Margin of Error for HH Income (%)` = moe_pct,
    `Reliability Category` = category,
  )

selected_counties %>% 
  kable()










County
Median Household Income
Margin of Error for HH Income (%)
Reliability Category




Alameda
122488
1.004996
High Confidence


Alpine
101125
17.247960
Low Confidence


Amador
74853
8.079837
Moderate Confidence





Comment on the output: The % cateogory of marginal error directly reflects the reliability of the data. Where, lower the % of marginal error, higher reliability of data.

title: Lab 1: Census Data Quality for Policy Decisions
text:
3.2 Tract-Level Demographics
Your Task: Get demographic data for census tracts in your selected counties.
Requirements: - Geography: tract level - Variables: white alone (B03002_003), Black/African American (B03002_004), Hispanic/Latino (B03002_012), total population (B03002_001) - Use the same state and year as before - Output format: wide - Challenge: You’ll need county codes, not names. Look at the GEOID patterns in your county data for hints.

# Define your race/ethnicity variables with descriptive names
race_variables <- c(
  `White Alone` = "B03002_003",
  `Black/African American` = "B03002_004",
  `Hispanic/Latino` = "B03002_012",
  `Total Population` = "B03002_001"
)

# Use get_acs() to retrieve tract-level data
# Hint: You may need to specify county codes in the county parameter

county_levelcode <- c("001","003","005")
  

selected_counties_data <- get_acs(
  geography = "tract",
  variables = race_variables,
  county = county_levelcode,
  state = my_state,
  year = 2022,
  survey = "acs5",
  output = "wide"
)

tibble(selected_counties_data)

# A tibble: 390 × 10
   GEOID       NAME         `White AloneE` `White AloneM` Black/African Americ…¹
   <chr>       <chr>                 <dbl>          <dbl>                  <dbl>
 1 06001400100 Census Trac…           2255            444                    171
 2 06001400200 Census Trac…           1500            219                     38
 3 06001400300 Census Trac…           3290            378                    529
 4 06001400400 Census Trac…           2740            606                    499
 5 06001400500 Census Trac…           1638            262                    993
 6 06001400600 Census Trac…            905            183                    539
 7 06001400700 Census Trac…           2293            422                   1101
 8 06001400800 Census Trac…           2228            462                    643
 9 06001400900 Census Trac…           1052            266                    692
10 06001401000 Census Trac…           2095            531                   1478
# ℹ 380 more rows
# ℹ abbreviated name: ¹​`Black/African AmericanE`
# ℹ 5 more variables: `Black/African AmericanM` <dbl>,
#   `Hispanic/LatinoE` <dbl>, `Hispanic/LatinoM` <dbl>,
#   `Total PopulationE` <dbl>, `Total PopulationM` <dbl>

# Calculate percentage of each group using mutate()

percentage_eachgroup <- selected_counties_data %>%
  mutate(
    pct_white = (`White AloneE`/`Total PopulationE`)*100,
    pct_Black = (`Black/African AmericanE`/`Total PopulationE`)*100,
    pct_Hisp = (`Hispanic/LatinoE`/`Total PopulationE`)*100
    ) %>%
  # Create percentages for white, Black, and Hispanic populations
  mutate(`Percentage of White, Black and Hispanic Populations`= pct_white + pct_Black + pct_Hisp, 
 # Add readable tract and county name columns using str_extract() or similar
         Tract =  str_extract(NAME, "[0-9.]+"),
         County = str_extract(NAME, "[A-Za-z ]+ County"))%>% 
  select(County, Tract,
         `White %` = "pct_white",
         `Black %`= "pct_Black",
         `Hispanic or Latino %`="pct_Hisp", 
         `Percentage of White, Black and Hispanic Populations`,
        )
tibble(percentage_eachgroup)

# A tibble: 390 × 6
   County            Tract `White %` `Black %` `Hispanic or Latino %`
   <chr>             <chr>     <dbl>     <dbl>                  <dbl>

title: Lab 1: Census Data Quality for Policy Decisions
text:
3.3 Demographic Analysis
Your Task: Analyze the demographic patterns in your selected areas.

# Find the tract with the highest percentage of Hispanic/Latino residents
# Hint: use arrange() and slice() to get the top tract
hisp_high <- percentage_eachgroup %>%
  arrange(desc(`Hispanic or Latino %`))%>%
  slice_head(n=1)%>%
  select(County,`Hispanic or Latino %`)
tibble(hisp_high)%>%
  kable()




County
Hispanic or Latino %




Alameda County
85




# Calculate average demographics by county using group_by() and summarize()
# Show: number of tracts, average percentage for each racial/ethnic group
county_summary <- percentage_eachgroup %>%
  group_by(County)%>%
  summarise(`Number of Tracts`=n(),
            `Average White Percentage` = mean(`White %`, na.rm = TRUE),
            `Average Black Percentage` = mean(`Black %`, na.rm = TRUE),
            `Average Hispanic Percentage` = mean(`Hispanic or Latino %`, na.rm = TRUE)
    
  )%>%
  select(
    County,
    `Number of Tracts`,
    `Average White Percentage`,
    `Average Black Percentage`,
    `Average Hispanic Percentage`
    )
tibble(county_summary)%>% 
  kable()

title: Lab 1: Census Data Quality for Policy Decisions
text:
4.1 MOE Analysis for Demographic Variables
Your Task: Examine margins of error for demographic variables to see if some communities have less reliable data.
Requirements: - Calculate MOE percentages for each demographic variable - Flag tracts where any demographic variable has MOE > 15% - Create summary statistics

# Calculate MOE percentages for white, Black, and Hispanic variables
# Hint: use the same formula as before (margin/estimate * 100)
tibble(selected_counties_data)

# A tibble: 390 × 10
   GEOID       NAME         `White AloneE` `White AloneM` Black/African Americ…¹
   <chr>       <chr>                 <dbl>          <dbl>                  <dbl>
 1 06001400100 Census Trac…           2255            444                    171
 2 06001400200 Census Trac…           1500            219                     38
 3 06001400300 Census Trac…           3290            378                    529
 4 06001400400 Census Trac…           2740            606                    499
 5 06001400500 Census Trac…           1638            262                    993
 6 06001400600 Census Trac…            905            183                    539
 7 06001400700 Census Trac…           2293            422                   1101
 8 06001400800 Census Trac…           2228            462                    643
 9 06001400900 Census Trac…           1052            266                    692
10 06001401000 Census Trac…           2095            531                   1478
# ℹ 380 more rows
# ℹ abbreviated name: ¹​`Black/African AmericanE`
# ℹ 5 more variables: `Black/African AmericanM` <dbl>,
#   `Hispanic/LatinoE` <dbl>, `Hispanic/LatinoM` <dbl>,
#   `Total PopulationE` <dbl>, `Total PopulationM` <dbl>

moe_race <- selected_counties_data %>%
  mutate(
    `MOE % White` = (`White AloneM` / `White AloneE`)*100,
    `MOE % Black` = (`Black/African AmericanM` / `Black/African AmericanE`)*100,
    `MOE % Hispanic` = (`Hispanic/LatinoM` / `Hispanic/LatinoE`)*100,

# Create a flag for tracts with high MOE on any demographic variable
# Use logical operators (| for OR) in an ifelse() statement
Flag = ifelse(
     `MOE % White` > 15 | `MOE % Black` > 15 | `MOE % Hispanic` > 15, "UNRELIABLE", "  ")
    )
tibble(moe_race)

# A tibble: 390 × 14
   GEOID       NAME         `White AloneE` `White AloneM` Black/African Americ…¹
   <chr>       <chr>                 <dbl>          <dbl>                  <dbl>
 1 06001400100 Census Trac…           2255            444                    171
 2 06001400200 Census Trac…           1500            219                     38
 3 06001400300 Census Trac…           3290            378                    529
 4 06001400400 Census Trac…           2740            606                    499
 5 06001400500 Census Trac…           1638            262                    993
 6 06001400600 Census Trac…            905            183                    539
 7 06001400700 Census Trac…           2293            422                   1101
 8 06001400800 Census Trac…           2228            462                    643
 9 06001400900 Census Trac…           1052            266                    692
10 06001401000 Census Trac…           2095            531                   1478
# ℹ 380 more rows
# ℹ abbreviated name: ¹​`Black/African AmericanE`
# ℹ 9 more variables: `Black/African AmericanM` <dbl>,
#   `Hispanic/LatinoE` <dbl>, `Hispanic/LatinoM` <dbl>,
#   `Total PopulationE` <dbl>, `Total PopulationM` <dbl>, `MOE % White` <dbl>,
#   `MOE % Black` <dbl>, `MOE % Hispanic` <dbl>, Flag <chr>

# Create summary statistics showing how many tracts have data quality issues
summary <- moe_race %>% 
  summarise(
  tracts = n(),
  `tracts with issues` = sum(Flag == "UNRELIABLE")
) 
print(summary)

# A tibble: 1 × 2
  tracts `tracts with issues`
   <int>                <int>
1    390                  390

title: Lab 1: Census Data Quality for Policy Decisions
text:
4.2 Pattern Analysis
Your Task: Investigate whether data quality problems are randomly distributed or concentrated in certain types of communities.

# Group tracts by whether they have high MOE issues
# Calculate average characteristics for each group:
# - population size, demographic percentages
# Use group_by() and summarize() to create this comparison
# Create a professional table showing the patterns

moe_issuesummary <- moe_race %>%
  group_by(Flag) %>%
  summarise(
    tracts = n(),
    `Average Population` = mean(`Total PopulationE`, na.rm = TRUE),
    `Average White Population %` = mean((`White AloneE` / `Total PopulationE`) * 100, na.rm = TRUE),
    `Average Black Population %` = mean((`Black/African AmericanE` / `Total PopulationE`) * 100, na.rm = TRUE),
    `Average Hispanic Population %` = mean((`Hispanic/LatinoE` / `Total PopulationE`) * 100, na.rm = TRUE)
  )

  tibble(moe_issuesummary) %>%
  kable(
    caption = "Average Tract Characteristics by Data Quality Status"
  )


Average Tract Characteristics by Data Quality Status










Flag
tracts
Average Population
Average White Population %
Average Black Population %
Average Hispanic Population %




UNRELIABLE
390
4374.141
32.25342
10.44288
21.19834





Pattern Analysis: In my selected counties, all 390 census tracts are flagged as unreliable, meaning there is no meaningful contrast between reliable and unreliable areas. These tracts are relatively small, with an average population of about 4,374 residents, which helps explain the uniformly high margins of error. While White, Black, and Hispanic populations are present at non-negligible levels across tracts, the high uncertainty affects all groups similarly, indicating that unreliability is driven primarily by small population sizes and ACS sampling limitations rather than demographic composition. As a result, tract-level estimates in these counties are particularly vulnerable to error, making them risky inputs for algorithmic decision-making that depends on precise demographic thresholds.

title: Lab 1: Census Data Quality for Policy Decisions
text:
5.1 Analysis Integration and Professional Summary
Your Task: Write an executive summary that integrates findings from all four analyses.
Executive Summary Requirements: 1. Overall Pattern Identification: What are the systematic patterns across all your analyses? 2. Equity Assessment: Which communities face the greatest risk of algorithmic bias based on your findings? 3. Root Cause Analysis: What underlying factors drive both data quality issues and bias risk? 4. Strategic Recommendations: What should the Department implement to address these systematic issues?
Executive Summary:
The overall analysis focused on the reliability of ACS data for median household income at the county level and racial and ethnic composition at the census-tract level shows a clear understanding of how data reliability varies across measures. Data reliability differs by both variable and geographic or political division. County-level income estimates are mostly reliable, with almost 70 percent of counties providing data where the margin of error falls below 5 percent. In contrast, census-tract-level racial composition data are largely unreliable. For the randomly selected counties, regardless of income data reliability, racial data reliability remained consistently low. Out of 390 census tracts analyzed, all exhibited unreliable racial or ethnic estimates failing the 15% threshold.
Data reliability is especially weak for race and ethnicity variables, primarily because margins of error are high across tracts. This suggests a need to reconsider current data collection approaches. Census tracts in the analysis have relatively small populations, averaging around 4,000 residents. A general inference from the results is that smaller population sizes are associated with higher margins of error. As a result, existing ACS sampling and data collection methods may require revision to produce more reliable tract-level estimates.
The root cause of these issues appears to lie in the sampling design and overall data collection methodology. Capturing a larger effective sample would be necessary to improve reliability. In the long term, reconsidering census tract sizing or adopting alternative aggregation strategies may be necessary to support more stable and reliable data collection in the future.
The Department of Human Services should adopt an uncertainty-aware approach to decision-making by incorporating margins of error directly into analytical and algorithmic processes rather than relying on point estimates alone. Census tract level racial and ethnic composition data should not be used in isolation under current reliability conditions and should instead be aggregated to higher geographies or supplemented with additional data. A tiered framework based on data reliability should guide when automated decisions are appropriate versus when further review is required. Finally, reliability flags and margin of error measures should be clearly documented and carried through all outputs so uncertainty is visible at the point of decision

title: Lab 1: Census Data Quality for Policy Decisions
text:
6.3 Specific Recommendations
Your Task: Create a decision framework for algorithm implementation.

# Create a summary table using your county reliability data
# Include: county name, median income, MOE percentage, reliability category

# Add a new column with algorithm recommendations using case_when():
# - High Confidence: "Safe for algorithmic decisions"
# - Moderate Confidence: "Use with caution - monitor outcomes"  
# - Low Confidence: "Requires manual review or additional data"

# Format as a professional table with kable()

summary_overall <- ca_county_reliability %>%
  select(
    County,
    `Median Household Income`,
    `Margin of Error for HH Income (%)` = moe_pct, 
    `Reliability Category` = category
  )%>%
  mutate(
    `Algorithm Recommendation` = case_when(
    `Reliability Category` == "High Confidence" ~ "Safe for Algorithmic Decisions",
    `Reliability Category` == "Moderate Confidence" ~ "Use with caution - monitor outcomes",
    `Reliability Category` == "Low Confidence" ~ "Requires manual review or additional data"
    )
  )
tibble(summary_overall)%>%
  kable(caption = "County Income Data Reliability and Guide for Data Use - Algorithmic Recommendations <br> <em>For ethnic and race related analysis manual analysis and further data cleaning required")


County Income Data Reliability and Guide for Data Use - Algorithmic Recommendations  For ethnic and race related analysis manual analysis and further data cleaning required

Key Recommendations:
Your Task: Use your analysis results to provide specific guidance to the department.

Counties suitable for immediate algorithmic implementation: Alameda; Butte; Calaveras; Contra Costa; El Dorado; Fresno; Humboldt; Imperial; Kern; Kings; Lake; Los Angeles; Madera; Marin; Mendocino; Merced; Monterey; Napa; Nevada; Orange; Placer; Riverside; Sacramento; San Bernardino; San Diego; San Francisco; San Joaquin; San Luis Obispo; San Mateo; Santa Barbara; Santa Clara; Santa Cruz; Shasta; Siskiyou; Solano; Sonoma; Stanislaus; Sutter; Tulare; Ventura; Yolo; Yuba.


These are high reliability for income with margin of error below 5%.


Counties requiring additional oversight: Amador; Colusa; Del Norte; Glenn; Inyo; Lassen; Mariposa; Modoc; San Benito; Tehama; Tuolumne.


Frequent audits for analysis required, intervention in terms of surveying residents for the outcomes from decisions made by the planning department.


Counties needing alternative approaches: Alpine; Mono; Plumas; Sierra; Trinity. -Manual review of data- rezoning considerations (redrawing boundaries), frequent surveying and more direct community level engagement required.

title: Lab 1: Census Data Quality for Policy Decisions
text:
Questions for Further Investigation

Are high margins of error clustered in specific types of places, such as rural or low-population areas, rather than being randomly distributed across counties and census tracts?
Is it possible to analyze the spatial patterns and see if rezoning of census tracts is possible for added data reliability.

title: Lab 1: Census Data Quality for Policy Decisions
text:
Submission Checklist
Before submitting your portfolio link on Canvas:

All code chunks run without errors
All “[Fill this in]” prompts have been completed
Tables are properly formatted and readable
Executive summary addresses all four required components
Portfolio navigation includes this assignment
Census API key is properly set
Document renders correctly to HTML

Remember: Submit your portfolio URL on Canvas, not the file itself. Your assignment should be accessible at your-portfolio-url/labs/lab_1/your_file_name.html

title: MUSA 5080 Portfolio
text:
This portfolio documents my learning journey in Public Policy Analytics (MUSA 5080).


Advanced spatial analysis and data science for urban planning and public policy.




Weekly Notes: My learning reflections and key concepts
Labs: Completed assignments and analyses
Final Project: Capstone modeling challenge




Shubhanga Satyal
I am taking public policy analysis to understand how planning decisions are shaped by laws, budgets, political constraints, and institutional incentives, not just technical design. The course strengthens my ability to evaluate policy impacts, compare alternatives using data and economic reasoning, and make evidence-based recommendations that translate planning ideas into implementable outcomes.




Email: ssatyal@upenn.edu
GitHub: ssatyal-ux
